questions.text: Which of the following structures is most closely related to the development of both ventral and dorsal mesentery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ventral mesentery attaches dorsally to the stomach and is also called the ventral mesogastrium. The cranial part of the dorsal mesentery attaches to the stomach and is called the dorsal mesogastrium. 

Explanation of Other Options:

Liver(Option D): The liver develops within the ventral mesentery (specifically the septum transversum), but it is not the primary structure associated with both dorsal and ventral mesenteries.

Spleen(Option C): The spleen develops within the dorsal mesogastrium, not both mesenteries.

Duodenum(Option D): The duodenum is initially suspended by both mesenteries, but later becomes retroperitoneal due to fusion with the posterior body wall. It is influenced by stomach rotation, but not primarily responsible for both mesenteries.

questions.text: The muscular wall of the esophagus arises from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The muscle of the upper portion of the esophagus is skeletal muscle, derived from branchial arch VI and innervated by recurrent laryngeal branches of the vagus nerve, X.
  • The lower part of the esophageal wall is smooth muscle from splanchnic mesoderm, like the rest of the gut wall.
  • It is innervated by parasympathetics from the vagus.

Explanation of Other Options:

Somatic mesoderm(Option A): Somatic mesoderm contributes to body wall structures, limbs, and parietal peritoneum, but not directly to the esophageal muscle.

Neural crest(Option B): Neural crest cells give rise to structures such as:

  • Ganglia
  • Schwann cells
  • Craniofacial skeleton
    They do not form the muscle of the esophagus.

Lining of the yolk sac(Option D): This gives rise to endodermal gut tube lining, not muscular tissue.

choices.text: D) Reflux of milk through the nose and mouth, which appears toward the end of the first week after birth

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with esophageal atresia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reflux of milk through the nose and mouth, which appears toward the end of the first week after birth not typically associated with esophageal atresia. The symptoms of esophageal atresia (like frothy secretions, choking, and milk regurgitation) appear almost immediately after birth, not delayed until the end of the first week.

Esophageal Atresia and Tracheoesophageal Fistula (TEF):

These anomalies result from abnormal development of the tracheoesophageal septum, the structure that separates the trachea from the esophagus during embryogenesis.

Most Common Type:

  • The proximal esophagus ends in a blind pouch, while the distal esophagus connects to the trachea via a narrow fistulous tract, typically located just above the tracheal bifurcation.
  • This is known as Type C TEF (most common variant, ~85%).

Other Types:

  • Less common types include:
    • Isolated esophageal atresia (no fistula)
    • H-type fistula (fistula without atresia)
    • Double fistula with both proximal and distal esophageal communications to the trachea

Associated Conditions:

Polyhydramnios:(Option B ruled out)

  • Esophageal atresia prevents the fetus from swallowing amniotic fluid, leading to the accumulation of fluid in the amniotic sac.
  • Result: Polyhydramnios (excess amniotic fluid), often detected on prenatal ultrasound.

Esophageal Stenosis:

  • May occur due to:
    • Incomplete recanalization of the esophagus
    • Vascular anomalies
    • Intrauterine vascular accidents that disrupt the blood supply
  • Most commonly affects the lower third of the esophagus.

Congenital Hiatal Hernia:

  • Results when the esophagus fails to lengthen properly, pulling the stomach upward through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm.
  • This causes part of the stomach to lie in the thoracic cavity, rather than the abdomen.

choices.text: It communicates directly with the lesser sac via the epiploic (omental) foramen
It becomes a retroperitoneal structure in the adult
The ascending colon is enclosed within its upper boundary
It consists of two layers of peritoneum only

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the greater omentum is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The greater omentum hangs from the greater curvature of the stomach and communicates with the lesser sac (omental bursa) via the epiploic foramen (of Winslow).

Explanation of Other Options:

It becomes a retroperitoneal structure in the adult(Option B): The greater omentum remains intraperitoneal, not retroperitoneal.

The ascending colon is enclosed within its upper boundary(Option C): The transverse colon, not the ascending colon, lies about the greater omentum's superior boundary.

It consists of two layers of peritoneum only(Option D): It is formed by four layers of peritoneum, two anterior and two posterior, that fuse during development.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries supply derivatives of the caudal portion of the foregut?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The celiac trunk is the artery of the caudal portion of the foregut, supplying the stomach, liver, gall bladder, pancreas, and upper portion of the duodenum. The superior mesenteric is considered the artery of the midgut, and the inferior mesenteric is considered the artery of the hindgut.

choices.text: It is a derivative of the foregut and the midgut
The yolk stalk is attached to the apex of the duodenal loop
It is supplied by branches of the foregut and midgut arteries
It becomes C-shaped as it develops and the stomach rotates

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the developing duodenum is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The yolk stalk (vitelline duct) connects the midgut to the yolk sac, and it is attached at the apex of the midgut loop, not the duodenal loop.
  • During duodenal development, epithelial growth temporarily closes its lumen.
  • The duodenum develops from the terminal part of the foregut and the cephalic part of the midgut, with the junction between the two located just distal to the origin of the liver bud. (Option A ruled out.)
  • As the stomach rotates, the duodenum begins to take on a C-shaped loop. This loop rotates to the right, a movement aided by the rapid enlargement of the pancreatic head, which causes the duodenum to shift from its initial midline position to the right side of the abdominal cavity. (Option D ruled out.)
  • As a result of this shift, most of the duodenum becomes retroperitoneal, attaching to the posterior abdominal wall. However, a small portion near the distal end, known as the duodenal cap, retains a mesentery and remains intraperitoneal.
  • During the second month of development, the lumen of the duodenum is temporarily obliterated due to epithelial cell proliferation. This is a normal event and is soon followed by recanalization, which restores the passageway within the duodenum.
  • Due to its dual embryological origin, the duodenum receives a dual blood supply — branches from the celiac artery supply the foregut-derived portion, and branches from the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) supply the midgut-derived portion. (Option C ruled out.)

questions.text: The following embryonic structures can give rise to cysts, diverticula, or fistulae in postnatal life, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ductus venosus (of Botallo): Does not cause cysts, diverticula, or fistulae

  • This vessel shunts blood from the umbilical vein to the IVC, bypassing the liver in fetal life.
  • After birth, it closes normally and becomes the ligamentum venosum.
  • It does not leave behind epithelial-lined tracts that could result in postnatal cysts or fistulas.


Explanation of Other Options:

Vitelline duct(Option A):

  • The vitelline duct connects the midgut to the yolk sac in early development.
  • Failure to obliterate this duct can result in:
    • Meckel's diverticulum
    • Vitelline cyst
    • Umbilicoileal fistula

Urachus (Allantoic duct)(Option B):

  • The urachus connects the fetal bladder to the umbilicus.
  • Failure to regress can cause:
    • Urachal cyst
    • Urachal sinus
    • Urachal fistula

Neural tube(Option D):

  • Incomplete closure or abnormal development can result in:
    • Neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida cystica)
    • Dermoid cysts
    • Sinus tracts and fistulas (especially midline)

choices.text: The ventral border of the stomach moves to the right
The dorsal border moves to the left
The dorsal mesogastrium is carried to the left
The dorsal part of the stomach grows more rapidly

questions.text: As the stomach acquires its adult shape, it rotates around its longitudinal axis. Which of the following events does not result from this rotation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The dorsal wall of the stomach (future greater curvature) enlarges more rapidly than the ventral wall, but not related to rotation, instead related to differentiation.
  • This change in curvature occurs due to asymmetric growth, not because of the rotation.
  • This unequal growth gives the stomach its curved shape even before the rotation takes place.

During stomach rotation, the original ventral border comes to face to the right & superiorly, while the original dorsal border comes to face left & inferiorly. Duodenum rotates to the right, and the dorsal mesogastrium is carried to the left.

Explanation of Other Options:

The ventral border of the stomach moves to the right(Option A):

  • During the longitudinal rotation of the stomach (clockwise), the ventral (anterior) border of the stomach, which forms the lesser curvature, moves toward the right side of the embryo.
  • This rotation positions the lesser curvature on the right and the greater curvature on the left.

The dorsal border moves to the left(Option B):

  • As the stomach rotates, its dorsal (posterior) border, which becomes the greater curvature, swings to the left.
  • This shift is a direct consequence of the stomach's clockwise rotation around its longitudinal axis.

The dorsal mesogastrium is carried to the left(Option C):

  • The dorsal mesogastrium, which suspends the stomach from the posterior abdominal wall, is also affected by the stomach's rotation.
  • It is drawn to the left, creating a space behind the stomach known as the lesser sac (omental bursa).

questions.text: Gut rotations and subsequent fusion of mesentery to the dorsal body wall cause which of the following to assume a retroperitoneal position?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Due to gut rotation and mesentery fusions, most of the pancreas and duodenum, and the ascending and descending colons, become secondarily retroperitoneal.
  • The Pancreas becomes secondarily retroperitoneal.
  • Initially intraperitoneal, but after rotation of the duodenum and stomach, the dorsal mesentery of the pancreas fuses with the posterior abdominal wall.
  • The head, neck, and body of the pancreas become retroperitoneal. Only the tail remains intraperitoneal within the splenorenal ligament.

Explanation of Other Options:

Gall bladder(Option A): It develops from the hepatic diverticulum and stays suspended within the peritoneal cavity, attached to the liver, and does not become retroperitoneal.

Spleen(Option C): The spleen arises from mesenchyme in the dorsal mesogastrium and remains freely suspended in the peritoneal cavity by ligaments like the gastrosplenic and splenorenal.

Jejunum(Option D): It develops from the midgut and retains its mesentery (mesentery proper), allowing it to stay mobile and intraperitoneal.

choices.text: The pancreas arises from dorsal and ventral endodermal buds of the duodenum
Annular pancreas results from abnormal rotation of the dorsal bud
Insulin secretion begins only after birth

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pancreatic development is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pancreas forms from endodermal diverticula from the hepatic bud and the duodenum. The ventral bud develops into the uncinate process, but if it rotates abnormally, it can cause an annular pancreas.

  • During gut rotation, the ventral bud rotates posteriorly (around the duodenum) to fuse with the dorsal bud by the 7th week.
  • After fusion:
    • The dorsal bud gives rise to:
      • Body, tail, and part of the head of the pancreas
    • Ventral bud gives rise to:
      • Uncinate process and the inferior part of the head
    • The main pancreatic duct (of Wirsung) is formed mainly from the ventral duct and the distal dorsal duct
    • Accessory duct (of Santorini) (if present) comes from the proximal dorsal duct

Explanation of Other Options:

The ventral pancreatic bud degenerates(Option B): The ventral bud does not degenerate. It rotates posteriorly and fuses with the dorsal bud to form part of the head and uncinate process.

Annular pancreas results from abnormal rotation of the dorsal bud(Option C): An annular pancreas is due to abnormal migration of the ventral bud, not the dorsal. It can encircle the duodenum and cause obstruction.

Insulin secretion begins only after birth(Option D): Insulin is secreted by fetal pancreatic β-cells by the 10th week of gestation.

choices.text: The liver receives oxygenated blood from the placenta via the umbilical vein, which runs within the falciform ligament
The liver originates as an endodermal outgrowth from the distal foregut
Hematopoietic and connective tissue elements of the liver arise from mesodermal cells of the septum transversum
All of the above are correct

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the embryological development of the liver is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Liver develops from an endodermal hepatic diverticulum, but also contains mesodermal hemopoietic & connective tissue.

Blood from the placenta reaches the liver via the left umbilical vein but by-passes the sinusoids through the ductus venosus. The sinusoids are derived from the vitelline veins.

Option A: The umbilical vein brings oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus and passes through the falciform ligament en route to the liver. This vein is partially shunted through the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava.

Option B: The liver forms as a hepatic diverticulum from the endoderm of the distal foregut, near the junction of the foregut and midgut.

Option C: The hematopoietic cells, Kupffer cells, and connective tissue of the liver are mesodermal in origin, specifically from the septum transversum (a mass of mesenchyme between the heart and developing liver).

questions.text: The yolk sac detaches from the gut by the end of the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During embryological development, the yolk sac is initially connected to the midgut through the vitelline duct (omphalomesenteric duct).

  • Around the 5th week of development, the yolk sac detaches from the midgut as the vitelline duct gradually regresses
  • Normally, the vitelline duct completely disappears by the end of the 7th week.
  • Failure of this duct to regress can lead to Meckel's diverticulum, vitelline cyst, or umbilicoileal fistula.

questions.text: A persistence of the vitelline duct may result in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • If the vitelline duct remains patent, there will be an umbilical or vitelline fistula, leaking meconium or fetal feces at the umbilicus.
  • Partial closure of the vitelline duct may result in a vitelline cyst or a Meckel's/ileal diverticulum. The latter are found on the anti-mesenteric side of the ileum within 2 feet of the cecum.
  • The vitelline duct normally obliterates by the 7th week of development

Ileal diverticulum(Option A) (Meckel's diverticulum):

  • Partial persistence of the vitelline duct attached to the ileum.
  • Located on the antimesenteric border ~2 feet from the ileocecal valve.
  • May contain ectopic gastric or pancreatic tissue.
  • It can cause bleeding, inflammation, or obstruction.
  • Most common anomaly (~2% of population).

Umbilical fistula(Option B) (Patent vitelline duct):

  • Complete persistence of the duct.
  • Forms a direct connection between the ileum and the umbilicus.
  • Fecal discharge from the umbilicus is a key clinical sign.
  • Requires surgical correction.

Vitelline cyst(Option C) (Enterocyst):

  • Persistence of the middle segment of the duct.
  • Forms a cystic swelling along the path between the ileum and the umbilicus.
  • Connected by fibrous cords on both sides.
  • May present as a midline abdominal mass.

choices.text: Failure of the perforation of the anal membrane
Incomplete separation of the cloaca by the urorectal septum
Failure of recanalization of the colon

questions.text: A newborn boy had no passage of meconium for two days after birth. Examination revealed anal agenesis with perineal fistula. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Incomplete separation of the cloaca by the urorectal septum causes anal agenesis.
  • When the urorectal septum is formed, the cloacal membrane gets divided into the urogenital membrane anteriorly and the anal membrane posteriorly.
  • The ectoderm in the region of the future anal opening is called the proctodeum. The proctodeum invaginates and creates the anal pit.
  • The anal membrane now separates the hindgut from the anal pit.

Formation of the anal canal takes place as follows:

  • The upper part of the anal canal is formed by the endodermal hindgut and the lower part by the ectodermal anal pit.
  • The anal membrane in between breaks around the 9th week, and the anal canal becomes continuous.
  • The junction between the endodermal and the ectodermal region of the anal canal is marked by the pectinate line.

Explanation of Other Options:

Degeneration of the anal membrane(Option A): The anal membrane is a transient structure that normally degenerates around the 8th week to create the anal opening; degeneration is a normal process, not a pathological cause.

Failure of the perforation of the anal membrane(Option B): If the anal membrane fails to perforate, it results in an imperforate anus, where the rectum ends blindly; no external fistula is typically present in this case.

Failure of recanalization of the colon(Option D): The colon undergoes a temporary occlusion during development, followed by recanalization; failure of this process can lead to colonic atresia or stenosis, not anal agenesis or perineal fistula.

questions.text: The midgut loop normally herniates through the primitive umbilical ring into the extra-embryonic coelom during the 6th week of development. Failure of the intestinal loops to return to the abdominal cavity by the 11th week results in the formation of which of the following conditions in a baby?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Failure of the intestinal loops to return to the abdominal cavity during the 6th to 10th weeks results in omphalocele or exomphalos.
  • Omphalocele is a congenital malformation in which the abdominal viscera protrude through a wide umbilical defect. The bowel loops are covered by amnion.
  • A small omphalocele contains only the intestines. A large omphalocele may contain other viscera such as the stomach, liver, spleen, and large intestine, along with the small intestine.
  • Omphalocele is commonly associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and causes increased levels of a-fetoprotein.

Explanation of Other Options:

Gastroschisis(Option B): A defect lateral to the umbilicus (usually right side), where intestines herniate directly into the amniotic cavity without a covering membrane. It is not due to failure of midgut return, but due to abnormal closure of the lateral body folds.

Exstrophy of the bladder(Option C): A rare congenital condition where the bladder is exposed on the abdominal wall due to failure in closure of the infraumbilical midline. It does not involve intestinal herniation.

Ileal diverticulum (Meckel’s diverticulum)(Option D): A remnant of the vitelline duct, it is a small outpouching of the ileum. It does not cause herniation of the intestine and is unrelated to failure of midgut return.

questions.text: Mesoderm of which of the following structures gives rise to the spleen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The spleen develops from the mesoderm in the dorsal mesogastrium.
  • The mesenchymal cells in the dorsal mesogastrium form small lobular masses of splenic tissue called spleniculi. Later, these lobules fuse to form a single mass of the spleen.
  • The capsule, septa, and connective tissue framework, including reticular fibers, develop from mesoderm.
  • The mesenchymal cells also differentiate into lymphoblasts and other blood-forming cells.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ventral mesogastrium(Option A): Gives rise to structures like the lesser omentum, falciform ligament, and helps position the liver, not the spleen.

Dorsal mesoduodenum(Option C): Suspends the duodenum during development; not involved in spleen formation.

Septum transversum(Option D): Contributes to the diaphragm and liver stroma, but not the spleen.

questions.text: The fibrous stroma of the liver is derived from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The fibrous stroma of the liver is derived from the septum transversum.
  • The liver develops as an outgrowth of the endodermal epithelium at the distal end of the foregut.
  • This liver bud or hepatic diverticulum proliferates rapidly and penetrates the septum transversum.

During embryonic development, the liver develops from two primary sources:

  • Endoderm of the foregut gives rise to:
    • Hepatocytes
    • Bile canaliculi
    • Biliary epithelium (e.g., lining of bile ducts)
  • The mesoderm of the septum transversum gives rise to:
    • Fibrous stroma (connective tissue framework) of the liver
    • Kupffer cells (via mesenchyme)
    • Hematopoietic cells (temporarily)

Explanation of Other Options:

Foregut endoderm(Option A): Gives rise to hepatocytes and bile duct epithelium, not the fibrous stroma.

Midgut endoderm(Option B):  Forms distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum. Not related to the liver.

Hindgut endoderm(Option C): Forms colon, rectum. Unrelated to liver development.

questions.text: An infant was admitted to the NICU as she was suffering from severe dyspnea and cyanosis. Chest X-ray revealed hypoplastic left lung and herniation of the intestines into the left thoracic cavity. Abnormality in which of the following structures during embryonic development will most commonly lead to the given condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia. It most commonly occurs due to the failure of fusion of the pleuroperitoneal folds during the development of the diaphragm.

The diaphragm develops from 4 mesodermal sources as follows:

  • Septum transversum becomes the anterior and medial part of the diaphragm, including the central tendon
  • Pleuroperitoneal membranes (paired structures) become the dorsolateral parts of the diaphragm
  • The mesoderm of the body wall from somites of cervical segments three to five (C3-5) contributes to the peripheral muscular part
  • The mesentery of the esophagus forms the crura of the diaphragm

Explanation of Other Options:

Mesentery of the esophagus(Option A): Contributes to the formation of the crura of the diaphragm, not to the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal.

Pleuropericardial folds(Option B): These form the fibrous pericardium, not the diaphragm, associated with the separation of the pericardial and pleural cavities.

Body wall(Option C): Contributes muscle to the peripheral part of the diaphragm, but defects here don’t usually cause herniation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a remnant of the marked structure in an adult?
questions.solution:
Explanation: 

The medial umbilical ligament is the remnant of this structure. 

The umbilical artery has the following fate:

  • Proximal parts persist as the superior vesical arteries
  • Distal parts get obliterated and form the medial umbilical ligaments
